results.title: Vampire hunter D: bloodlust [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Yoshiaki Kawajiri, Masao Maruyama, Mata Yamamoto, Taka Nagasawa, Film Line International and Urban Vision Entertainment
results.brief_description: In this animated horror movie, set in a menacing distant future where the dead haunt the living, a deadly vampire kidnaps a beautiful human woman. Her distraught family offer a huge reward for her rescue - dead or alive. One bounty hunter, Dunpeal, a half-human, half-vampire being, at war with himself, tortured and alone, is hired to retrieve the girl. But a rival group of rescuers, the Marcus siblings, resent Dunpeal’s presence, and plan to use him in order to collect the loot. In his quest, D faces many nasty encounters with murderous semi-human creatures, including a werewolf, a shape-shifter, a phantom queen, and a subculture of human-hating monsters. In Vampire Hunter D: Bloodlust”, the sequel to “Vampire hunter D (1985), the future has the aesthetic of a dystopic, medieval nightmare but the animation is far more sophisticated than in the original. Director Yoshiaki Kawajiri (Wicked City, Animatrix) keeps the action exciting, even if the characterisations are simplistic, and the violent gory animatronics are awe-inspiring in scope, embodying all the qualities of gothic, bloody combat, whilst harking to the model of the eternal outsider, moody and disliked, shunned by society and feared by his enemies.

results.title: House on Haunted Hill
results.creator_credit: William Castle and Allied Artists Pictures
results.brief_description: Directed in 1958 by 50s B-grade horror maestro William Castle, “House on Haunted Hill” boasted the arrival of “Emergo”, a fluorescent skeleton that swept across the head of audience members in the cinema. Widowed playboy millionaire Frederick Loren (Vincent Price) invites 5 guests: a race driver, a columnist, the previous owner, a psychiatrist, and a typist to spend a night with Loren and his fourth wife, Annabelle, in the haunted house. At the strike of midnight the doors will close, the electricity will be out, and 12 hours lie ahead in a tenement in which there have been several mysterious deaths, including those of Loren’s previous 3 wives. The 4 men and 3 women have nothing in common, other than their need for money, and Loren has posted a reward of $10,000 for anyone who lasts the night. Low in budget, the film boasts several frightening scenes, including an acid bath and dismembered head, earning the film an M rating. Cast includes: Vincent Price, Richard Long, Alan Marshal, Carolyn Craig. Music composed and conducted by Castle collaborator Von Dexter. Remade in 1999 by William Malone.

results.title: Ned Kelly [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tony Richardson, Neil Hartley and Woodfall Film Productions
results.brief_description: Ned Kelly, an impoverished Irish Catholic, is driven to crime by the persecution of the English Protestant establishment and their agents, a corrupt police force. The powerful figures - judge, police chief, landowner - are presented as virtual caricatures. The film takes a folkloric approach in emphasising the general at the expense of the particular in portraying Ned’s grim existence. There is something of a mixture of styles. The setting is carefully established but the camerawork is lyrical rather than observational. At times (as in the white bull sequence) the film seems to approach abstraction while at others the mood borders on that of musical, even pseudo-Restoration comedy. Mick Jagger is subdued in the role of Ned to the point of subverting the legend. Music by Shel Silverstein. Cast also includes Allen Bickford, Geoff Gilmour, Mark McManus, Serge Lazareff, Peter Sumner, Ken Shorter, Diane Craig.

results.title: Wedding in Galilee = Noce en Galilee [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Michel Khleifi, LPA, Marisa Films and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: Abu Adel, the Mukhtar of a Palestinian village is given permission to hold a traditional wedding for his son on the condition that the Israeli military governor and his staff be guests of honor at the ceremony. Agreeing to the governor’s condition immediately created division and anger amongst his family, and the village community, resulting in a conspiracy by some of the younger men to sabotage the wedding and kill the governor and his soldiers. Conflict between families, the underlying tension between the Israelis and the wedding guests, failure of the groom to consummate his marriage, and the hatred which the groom has for his father, are just some of the many threads which weave this intriguing story together to provide an insight into the culture, contradictions and hostilities which exist in occupied Palestine. “Wedding in Galilee” was the first feature film made in Palestine by a Palestinian director, Michel Khleifi (Forbidden marriages in the Holy Land, 1995), who believes that “culture is meant to be controversial”. This international multi-award winning film is controversial in more ways than one with its blend of politics and culture, and sensuality and sexuality. Although a slow-moving, lyrical film, there is however, an underlying intensity, an expectation that disaster is imminent. Sadly and quite ironically, the Intifada began only six months after the film was shot. Cast includes Makram Khouri, Youssef Abou Wardeh, Jouliano Mer Khamis, Buchra Karaman, Anna Achdian, Nazih Akleh, Sonia Amar. (Awards: Cannes; San Sebastian; Belgium; Tunisia) In Arabic and Hebrew with English subtitles.

results.title: Tale of the three jewels = Conte des trois diamonts
results.creator_credit: Michel Khleifi, Omar Al-Qattan, Arte, BBC-TV, La Sept, Sindibad Films, Sourat Films and Television Espanola
results.brief_description: A beautiful film of young adolescent love, of dreams and fantasies, which sadly takes place in a world of conflict, hate and violence in the war-ravaged Gaza Strip. Twelve year-old Yusef (Mohammad Nahhal) lives in a refugee camp with his mother and older sister. His father is in prison and his older brother is on the run from the Israeli soldiers. To escape the surrounding violence Yusef constantly lives in an imaginary world, but it is his bird hunting in the near-by countryside that allows Yusef a sense of freedom and space. It is here that Yusef meets Aida (Hana Nemah), the wild and lovely young gypsy girl from a local gypsy camp, whose beguiling eyes and smile Yusef finds hard to resist. He soon declares his love for Aida telling her he will marry her when they grow up. However Aida sets a task for Yusef before she will agree to marriage, that being he must first find three jewels missing from her grandmother’s necklace, which was brought from South America by her grandfather. And so the adventure begins as Yusef, determined, sets out on his quest to find the three missing jewels with the help of Aida and his very close friend Salah (Ghassan Abur Libda) who comes from a wealthy and influential family of orange growers. These three young Palestinian friends from such disparate backgrounds are each portrayed sensitively by the young actors involved. Combine this with superb direction from Michel Khleifi (Wedding in Galilee, Forbidden marriages in the Holy Land), stunning cinematography by Raymond Fromont, and the fact that it is the first feature film ever to be shot in the Gaza Strip, makes “Tale of the three jewels” compelling viewing. Cast also includes Makram Khouri, Bushra Qaraman, Mohammad Bakri. Winner of several international awards. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Kermit's swamp years [DVD]
results.creator_credit: David Gumpel, Ritamarie Peruggi and Jim Henson Company
results.brief_description: Travelling down the road to his traditional home at “the swamp,” Kermit (Steve Whitmire) reflects on the good old days aged 12 with pals Croaker and Goggles as they mucked about in the swamp attempting to prove their braveness and pondering a life beyond theirs. When they actually make it to the end of the world as they know it and the road that leads to civilisation, the adventure of a lifetime begins as a pet-store owner who supplies frogs for a science class in which amphibians will be dissected, kidnaps Goggles. Kermit and Croaker, along with a shaggy dog who has just saved their lives, head into the city in search of their friend. It’s also during this time that Kermit discovers that he wants to be in the movies. Features a range of new Muppet characters that do not appear in “The Muppet show”. Features live and Muppet action. Cast also includes Bill Barretta, Dave Goelz and Joey Mazzarino.

results.title: In search of Anna
results.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Australian Film Commission, Storm Productions and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Tony has just been released from Pentridge after serving six years for robbery. He sets out to settle old scores and search for his girlfriend Anna. In the process he hitches a ride north with the enigmatic Sam and a relationship develops between them. The theme of coming to terms with the past is expressed formally through the non-chronological structure which produces a split narrative - the Melbourne scenes and the journey north - which inform each other as the story unfolds. Underlying the journey to awareness is the city/country antinomy - the country has the power to liberate what the city has entrapped. Features the music of AC/DC, Rose Tattoo, Stiletto, The Angels and Steve Wright. Cast includes Richard Moir, Judy Morris, Chris Haywood, Bill Hunter, Ian Nimmo, Maurie Fields.

results.title: A Taste of honey
results.creator_credit: Tony Richardson, Bryanston Films, Continental and Woodfall Film Productions
results.brief_description: A kitchen sink drama from the early 1960s, “A Taste of Honey” is about a young Englishwoman, who lives with her hard drinking, floozy of a mother, Helen. When Helen impulsively marries her current boyfriend, Jo is turned out and moves in with Geoffrey, a kindly homosexual friend, himself an outsider. Their peaceful domesticity is interrupted when Jo falls pregnant after an affair with a black sailor. After the birth of the baby, Jo and Geoffrey are effectively co-parenting until Jo’s opportunistic mother re-emerges to stake her claim in her daughter’s life. Despite its depressing subject matter “A Taste of honey” entertains a blackly comic tone that keeps it from sliding into a draining melodrama. The film is a fascinating ‘slice-of-life’ view of working class life in Britain of the 60s, whose entrancing black and white cinematography, reminiscent of Bill Brandt’s photography of working class England, contrasts with the gauche and drab reality of the characters’ surrounds. This controversial film dealt with many taboo topics on the day - teen pregnancy, inter-racial romance, homosexuality, child abandonment, without excessive sermonising on the topics, typical of American moral dramas of the 1950s. Cast includes Dora Bryan, Rita Tushingham, Robert Stephens, Murray Melvin, Paul Danquah and David Boliver.

When Helen impulsively marries her current boyfriend, Jo is turned out and moves in with Geoffrey, a kindly homosexual friend, himself an outsider. Their peaceful domesticity is interrupted when Jo falls pregnant after an affair with a black sailor. After the birth of the baby, Jo and Geoffrey are effectively co-parenting until Jo’s opportunistic mother re-emerges to stake her claim in her daughter’s life. Despite its depressing subject matter “A Taste of honey” entertains a blackly comic tone that keeps it from sliding into a draining melodrama. The film is a fascinating ‘slice-of-life’ view of working class life in Britain of the 60s, whose entrancing black and white cinematography, reminiscent of Bill Brandt’s photography of working class England, contrasts with the gauche and drab reality of the characters’ surrounds. This controversial film dealt with many taboo topics on the day - teen pregnancy, inter-racial romance, homosexuality, child abandonment, without excessive sermonising on the topics, typical of American moral dramas of the 1950s. Cast includes Dora Bryan, Rita Tushingham, Robert Stephens, Murray Melvin, Paul Danquah and David Boliver.

results.title: Silent Shakespeare
results.brief_description: In Silent Shakespeare, film historian Luke McKernan showcases a compilation of extracts from early film adaptations of the Bard’s more regularly performed plays. Sourced from nitrate prints in the National Film and Television Archive Collection, these extracts are unique for revealing the growing enthusiasm for, and enchantment with, the new medium. Film was initially viewed as the poor cousin of theatre. To combat its reputation of being cheap entertainment for the lower classes, film sought to emulate the highbrow success of the theatre by replicating its lavish venues, poaching its stars for screen roles, and adapting plays into films. Working within the limitations of early film cameras and the staginess of Shakespeare’s works, many of the early productions were hybrids between stage and screen, juxtaposing constructed sets and stage-like tableaux with location shooting, trick photography, hand stencilling, and colour tinting. Works included are King John (Great Britain, 1899), the first ever film adaptation of Shakespeare; The Tempest (Great Britain, 1908); A Midsummer night’s dream (USA, 1909); King Lear (Italy, 1910); Twelfth night (USA, 1910); The Merchant of Venice (Italy, 1910), and Richard III (Great Britain, 1911).

results.title: Jason and the Argonauts [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Don Chaffey, Charles H. Schneer and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Stemming from Greek mythology, this is the tale of the voyages of the intrepid Jason and his Argonauts on a quest to find the legendary Golden Fleece. He and his crew must brave all manner of dangers and face a host of terrifying foes, including the seven-headed Hydra, fighting skeletons, bloodthirsty Harpies and the invincible colossus Talos. It is also a tale of love, as the beautiful Medea risks everything for Jason and his quest. For its time, the special effects of Ray Harryhausen were given accolades by the critics. Stars Todd Armstrong as Jason and Nancy Kovack as Medea.

constellations_other.name: Sublime light and special effects
constellations_other.description: Explore 19th-century artist John Martin’s surprising influence on science fiction and fantasy films of the 20th century, from Jason and the Argonauts to the Lord of the Rings and the Evil Dead franchises.
